Knowledge Point: Otherwise, aspectuals are occasionally omitted clause-initially (and especially sen\-tence-initially) in an informal style, if the verb is followed by one or more postverbal particles. As the following examples show, different aspectuals can be omitted. In \REF{ex:7.1}, the perfect aspect marker ko is implied; the usual perfect aspect construction is \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā} (\sectref{sec:7.2.7}). In \REF{ex:7.2}, neutral he is implied: the verb is followed by \textit{rō {\ꞌ}ai}, which points towards the construction \textit{he V rō {\ꞌ}ai}\is{he (aspect marker)!he V rō {\ꞌ}ai} (\sectref{sec:7.2.3.3}); the second clause in \REF{ex:7.2} shows the same construction in full, with aspect marker.

Knowledge Point: In many cases, a he{}-marked clause depends on other clauses in the context for its aspectual value. In narrative, a perfective clause may set the scene, after which a series of he{}-marked clauses follow (see \REF{ex:7.4} below). Another example: he may mark a series of instructions, but only when the first of these is explicitly marked as imperative\is{Imperative} (see \REF{ex:7.5} below).

Knowledge Point: \paragraph{}\label{sec:7.2.3.2.4} He-marked clauses may express events that are about to happen or foreseen in the (near) future\is{Future}. The time frame is established in the context (‘next year’ in \REF{ex:7.10}).

Knowledge Point: Perfective aspect is naturally correlated with past tense \citep[72]{Comrie1976}, and in fact, i usually marks events in the past\is{Past}. I has been characterised as a past tense marker in several descriptions of Rapa Nui and other Polynesian languages.\footnote{\label{fn:320}See \citet[156]{DuFeu1996} for Rapa Nui, \citet{MutuTeìkitutoua2002} for \ili{Marquesan}, \citet[172]{AcadémieTahitienne1986} for \ili{Tahitian}, \citet[34]{Biggs1973} for \ili{Māori}. Note that \citet[153]{Chapin1978} labels Rapa Nui i as perfective.} In non-narrative contexts i is the common aspectual for past events, as the following examples show. As \REF{ex:7.17} shows, it may also express general facts about the past.
Content 1: \gll Te me\ꞌe o te mātāmu\ꞌa me\ꞌe ta\ꞌe vānaŋa, \textbf{i} \textbf{mou} \textbf{nō}. | \gls ART thing of ART past thing CONNEG talk PFV quiet just | \glt ‘The people of old used not to speak, they kept silent.’

Knowledge Point: There are cases, however, where i conveys a non-past event. For example, in \REF{ex:7.18} i is used with reference to the future:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{o\ꞌo} \textbf{era} koe ki roto i tu\ꞌu hare era e noho koe. | \gls PFV enter DIST 2SG to inside at POSS.2SG.O house DIST IPFV stay 2SG | \glt ‘When you have entered into your house, stay there.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Background} I{}-marked clauses may express background information. For example, in the introduction of a story, i{}-clauses may serve to set the stage by telling what happened before the beginning of the story, as in \REF{ex:7.24}. I-marked clauses may also express restatements or clarifications, as in \REF{ex:7.25}.\footnote{\label{fn:321}Similarly, i{}-marked clauses may express background events in subordinate clauses (\sectref{sec:11.6.2.2}).}

Knowledge Point: For Rapa Nui, the existing grammars offer little analysis on ka. \citet[63, 72]{Englert1978} does not list or discuss ka among the “tenses”, but only gives examples of its use in the imperative\is{Imperative}. According to \citet[37]{DuFeu1996} ka and ki are momentary particles indicating temporal relationships between actions; she gives examples of the use of ka in the imperative\is{Imperative} \REF{ex:7.37}, ka V rō\is{ka (aspect marker)!ka V rō} in the sense ‘until’ \REF{ex:7.51} and ka in temporal clauses\is{Clause!temporal} referring to the future. \citet[154]{Chapin1978} indicates that there are various other uses of ka besides the imperative\is{Imperative}, but that on the basis of his data, it is not possible to reach any satisfactory generalisation regarding these uses.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{mata} \textbf{nō} \textbf{\ꞌana} ho\ꞌi te miro era i hore mai era. | \gls IPFV unripe just CONT indeed ART wood DIST PFV cut hither DIST | \glt ‘The wood that has been cut is still green.’
Content 2: \gll ...he oho ararua ki Santiago ki te hare era o Ma\ꞌatea. \ꞌI ira ho\ꞌi \textbf{ka} \textbf{noho} \textbf{era}. | \gls ~~~NTR go the_two to Santiago to ART house DIST of Ma’atea at ANA indeed CNTG stay DIST | \glt ‘The two went to Santiago to the house of Ma’atea. There she would stay.’

Knowledge Point: In most of these examples, ka expresses temporal contiguity\is{Contiguity, temporal}. The event in the ka-clause is temporally contiguous to the event in the main clause; often it indicates a boundary to the event in the main clause as in \REF{ex:7.44}, \REF{ex:7.46} and \REF{ex:7.47}; sometimes the event overlaps with or is simultaneous to the main clause event as in \REF{ex:7.42}.

Content 2: \gll Mai ki hāpa\ꞌo nō tātou i a ia \textbf{\ꞌātā} \textbf{ka} nuinui \textbf{rō}. | \gls hither HORT care_for just 1PL.INCL ACC PROP 3SG until CNTG big:RED EMPH | \glt ‘Let us take care of him until he is big.’
Content 3: \gll He kai a Te Manu \textbf{ka} mākona \textbf{rō}. | \gls NTR eat PROP Te Manu CNTG satiated EMPH | \glt ‘Te Manu ate until he was satiated.’
Content 4: \gll He u\ꞌi atu, \textbf{ka} pū te manu taiko. | \gls NTR look away CNTG approach ART bird taiko | \glt ‘She saw a taiko bird come by.’

Knowledge Point: In these cases – different from the subordinate clauses in the previous section – the temporal/aspectual reference of the clause is not determined by its relation to surrounding clauses, but independently anchored in the non-linguistic context. For example, \REF{ex:7.50} forms a complete speech, so the sentence has no direct linguistic context. The contiguity mark\is{Contiguity, temporal}er indicates that the event is contiguous to the time of reference, in this case, the moment of speech.

Knowledge Point: Examples (\ref{ex:7.69}–\ref{ex:7.71}) show, that the use of the perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect} with a present sense is not limited to prototypical\is{Prototype} stative verbs\is{Verb!stative}. Verbs like \textit{{\ꞌ}ite}, \textit{ŋaro{\ꞌ}a} and haŋa are clearly active: they are transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verbs, the subject of which can be marked with the agent marker e (\sectref{sec:8.3.1.2}), yet they tend to have the perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect} marker\is{Aspect marker}.
Content 1: \gll Ko \textbf{haŋa} \ꞌā a ia mo oho mo hāpī. | \gls PRF want CONT PROP 3SG for go for learn | \glt ‘She wants to go to study.’
Content 2: \gll E nua, \ꞌi te hora nei ko \textbf{\ꞌite} \ꞌana a au i te parauti\ꞌa. | \gls VOC Mum at ART time PROX PRF know CONT PROP 1SG ACC ART truth | \glt ‘Mum, now I know the truth.’

Knowledge Point: These examples illustrate a typical use of i: in many cases, i{}-marked clauses express not just a past event, but an event which has a bearing on the present: the event has led to a state which is relevant right now. For example, in \REF{ex:7.74}, the subject has just arrived, leading to a situation in the present; ‘I came’ results in ‘I am here now’. And in \REF{ex:7.75}, ‘you won’ means as much as ‘OK, I give in, you win’, i.e. it describes a current situation, not just something which happened in the past. In other words, i is used in situations which seem to be similar to (\ref{ex:7.56}–\ref{ex:7.58}) in the previous section, where perfect aspect \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā} is used.
Content 1: \gll A au \textbf{i} \textbf{oho} \textbf{mai} \textbf{nei} ki a koe mo noho ō\ꞌoku \ꞌi nei. | \gls PROP 1SG PFV go hither PROX to PROP 2SG for stay POSS.1SG.O at PROX | \glt ‘I have come to you to live here.’
Content 2: \gll Ko koe \textbf{i} \textbf{rē}. | \gls PROM 2SG PFV win | \glt ‘You have won.’
Content 3: \gll Ko hiko \ꞌā tā\ꞌaku haraoa e Te Manu. | \gls PRF snatch CONT POSS.1SG.A bread AG Te Manu | \glt ‘My bread has been snatched by Te Manu.’
Content 4: \gll Ko haka moe \ꞌana \ꞌi rote \ꞌōpītara. | \gls PRF CAUS lie CONT at inside_ART hospital | \glt ‘They have put him into hospital.’

Knowledge Point: In this respect it is telling that the i-marked verb is often preceded by a subject\is{Subject!preverbal} (as in (\ref{ex:7.74}–\ref{ex:7.75})), while \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} with event/action verbs\footnote{\label{fn:336}With stative verbs\is{Verb!stative}, \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} does occur with preposed subjects. Using i with these verbs would rule out a stative interpretation. \textit{Ko V {\ꞌ}ā} also occurs with preverbal subjects\is{Subject!preverbal} after the deictic particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} (\sectref{sec:4.5.4.1.1}).} either has a subject after the verb or no subject at all; only very rarely is \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} preceded by a subject. As the default constituent order in Rapa Nui is verb—subject, initial subjects are more prominent than subjects following the verb. If \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} is more state-oriented while i is more event-oriented, it is not unexpected that the agent of an i{}-marked verb tends to be more prominent than the agent of a \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} marked verb.
Content 1: \gll A au \textbf{i} \textbf{oho} \textbf{mai} \textbf{nei} ki a koe mo noho ō\ꞌoku \ꞌi nei. | \gls PROP 1SG PFV go hither PROX to PROP 2SG for stay POSS.1SG.O at PROX | \glt ‘I have come to you to live here.’
Content 2: \gll Ko koe \textbf{i} \textbf{rē}. | \gls PROM 2SG PFV win | \glt ‘You have won.’

Knowledge Point: Noun phrases containing a numeral have a strong tendency to be sentence-initial, regardless their semantic relation to the verb; for example, they may be subject as in \REF{ex:7.77}, or adjunct as in \REF{ex:7.78}. After such a preverbal constituent the verb tends to be marked with i or e.
Content 1: \gll \obE rua nō hānau \ꞌe\ꞌepe taŋata\,\cb i rere mai. | \gls {\db}NUM two just race corpulent man PFV fly hither | \glt ‘Only two men from the ‘corpulent race’ jumped.’
Content 2: \gll \obE tahi mahana ta\ꞌato\ꞌa\,\cb i aŋa ai mo \ꞌauhau o tū ūtu\ꞌa era ō\ꞌona. | \gls {\db}NUM one day all PFV work PVP for pay of DEM punishment DIST POSS.3SG.O | \glt ‘One whole day he worked to pay his punishment.’

Knowledge Point: However, preverbal subjects followed by he are by no means uncommon. For examples, see \REF{ex:8.69} and \REF{ex:7.71} on p.~\pageref{ex:8.69}.
Content 1: \gll Mai tū hora era \textbf{a} \textbf{Eva} \ꞌina he taŋi haka\ꞌou. | \gls from DEM time DIST PROP Eva NEG NTR cry again | \glt ‘From that moment on Eva did not cry again.’
Content 2: \gll E nua, \ꞌi te hora nei ko \textbf{\ꞌite} \ꞌana a au i te parauti\ꞌa. | \gls VOC Mum at ART time PROX PRF know CONT PROP 1SG ACC ART truth | \glt ‘Mum, now I know the truth.’

Knowledge Point: However, this is not very common: usually rava + verb occurs after a noun, in a bare relative clause\is{Clause!relative!bare}. In these constructions, rava + V indicates an action which is not performed at a certain point in time, but which characterises the preceding noun. The expression has therefore a relatively time-stable character. A few examples:\footnote{\label{fn:341}In \REF{ex:7.88}, the noun is implied: ‘(the ones) given to sleeping’.}
Content 1: \gll ¡Ka \ꞌara, \textbf{rava} \textbf{ha\ꞌuru} kē, kōrua! | \gls ~IMP wake_up given_to sleep different 2PL | \glt ‘Wake up, you sleepyheads!’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:7.91}, \textit{{\ꞌ}apa} semantically quantifies the object: ‘we somewhat obtained X’ = ‘we obtained a few X’ (cf. (\ref{ex:7.95}–\ref{ex:7.96}) for a similar use of \textit{{\ꞌ}ata}).
Content 1: \gll Ko \textbf{\ꞌapa} rova\ꞌa mai \ꞌā te me\ꞌe pāreherehe matā. | \gls PRF part obtain hither CONT ART thing piece:RED obsidian | \glt ‘We obtained a few pieces of obsidian.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} te tāropa ana oho koe. | \gls EXH more carry ART basket IRR go 2SG | \glt ‘Take more baskets when you go.’
Content 3: \gll ¡\ꞌĒē, ka \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{ao} mai ki a au! | \gls ~yes IMP more serve_food hither to PROP 1SG | \glt ‘Yes please, serve me some more.’

Knowledge Point: With transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verbs, \textit{{\ꞌ}ata} may indicate a multiplication of the object. For example, in \REF{ex:7.95} \textit{{\ꞌ}ata} semantically modifies tāropa: ‘more baskets’.\footnote{\label{fn:344}Cf. the use of tahi and rahi in the verb phrase, sec. \sectref{sec:4.4.9} and \sectref{sec:4.4.7.2}.}
Content 1: \gll E \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} te tāropa ana oho koe. | \gls EXH more carry ART basket IRR go 2SG | \glt ‘Take more baskets when you go.’

Knowledge Point: With causative\is{Causative} verbs, the degree modifier usually occurs before the causative\is{Causative} prefix haka, as in \REF{ex:7.98}: ‘more [cause to be strong]’. However, it may also occur after haka, in which case haka has scope over the degree modifier. This is illustrated in \REF{ex:7.99}: ‘cause to be [more intelligent]’.
Content 1: \gll Ko \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{haka} \textbf{pūai} \ꞌana te re\ꞌo o Roŋotakahiu e pāta\ꞌuta\ꞌu era. | \gls PRF more CAUS strong CONT ART voice of Rongotakahiu IPFV recite DIST | \glt ‘Rongotakahiu sang louder (lit. strengthened his voice more when singing).’
Content 2: \gll ...te tire e haŋa rō \ꞌā mo \textbf{haka} \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{māramarama} i a rāua. | \gls ~~~ART Chilean IPFV want EMPH CONT for CAUS more intelligent ACC PROP 3PL | \glt ‘...Chileans who want to pass themself off as smarter (lit. to cause them to be smarter).’

Knowledge Point: With the constituent negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e}\is{tae (negator)@ta{\ꞌ}e (negator)}, either the negator or the degree particle may come first. In \REF{ex:7.100} the negator comes first and has scope over \textit{{\ꞌ}ata}\is{ata ‘more’@{\ꞌ}ata ‘more’}: ‘not [more high]’. In \REF{ex:7.101}, \textit{{\ꞌ}apa}\is{apa ‘part’@{\ꞌ}apa ‘part’} has scope over the negation: ‘somewhat [not listening]’.
Content 1: \gll Te tāvini \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{\ꞌata} \textbf{hau} ki te taŋata haka aŋa i a ia. | \gls ART servant CONNEG more exceed to ART man CAUS work ACC PROP 3SG | \glt ‘A servant is not higher than his master (lit. the man who makes him work).’
Content 2: \gll Te māmoe nei māmoe vara kori \ꞌe \textbf{\ꞌapa} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{hakaroŋo}. | \gls ART sheep PROX sheep usually play and part CONNEG listen | \glt ‘This lamb used to play and was somewhat disobedient.’

Knowledge Point: In the previous examples, a contrast is implied between what happens and what could have happened. Sometimes this sense of contrast is more prominent; the clause has a connotation of counterexpectation\is{Counterexpectation}: ‘even so, no matter, still’.\footnote{\label{fn:346}A contrastive sense of nō is also found in expressions like \textit{Te me{\ꞌ}e nō} ‘however’ (see \REF{ex:5.153} on p.~\pageref{ex:5.153}) and in the conjunction\is{Conjunction} nōatu (\sectref{sec:11.6.7}).}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Te} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{nō,} \ꞌi ruŋa i tū vaka era ō\ꞌona e ai rō \ꞌā e tahi pē\ꞌue, e rua miro \ꞌi te kaokao o te vaka. | \gls ART thing just at above at DEM boat DIST POSS.3SG.O IPFV exist EMPH CONT NUM one mat NUM two wood at ART side:RED of ART boat | \glt ‘(His boat was like the other ones;) however, in his boat there was a rug, and two poles on the sides of the boat.’

Knowledge Point: An action marked with nō is often unremarkable, routine, expected: something is simply going on, nothing significant has happened (yet). Often, the verb phrase expresses a lack of change with respect to a previous situation: the same thing described earlier is still going on. In this sense, nō is common in progressive\is{Progressive} cohesive clauses\is{Clause!cohesive} (see \REF{ex:11.213} on p.~\pageref{ex:11.213}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ha\ꞌuru} \textbf{nō} \textbf{\ꞌā} a Eva he hakaroŋo atu ko te re\ꞌo ka raŋi... | \gls IPFV sleep just CONT PROP Eva NTR listen away PROM ART voice CNTG call | \glt ‘When Eva was still asleep, she heard a voice calling...’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:5.8.2}, nō in the noun phrase often serves to limit the reference of a noun phrase. Occasionally, nō in the verb phrase has the same effect.\footnote{\label{fn:347}Cf. the use of tahi ‘all’, which occurs in the verb phrase but determines the reference of a noun phrase in the clause (\sectref{sec:4.4.9}).} In \REF{ex:7.111}, nō occurs after the (nominalised) verb kai, signalling that the object noun phrase has limited reference.
Content 1: \gll Ko ha\ꞌumani \ꞌana \ꞌi te \textbf{kai} \textbf{iŋa} \textbf{nō} i te moa. | \gls PRF bored CONT at ART eat NMLZ just ACC ART chicken | \glt ‘I’m tired of eating only chicken.’

Knowledge Point: Notice that \ili{English} ‘just’ can be used in the same way, as the translation of \REF{ex:7.113} shows.
Content 1: \gll Te pahī nei, he \textbf{nehenehe} \textbf{nō}. | \gls ART ship PROX NTR beautiful just | \glt ‘This ship was just beautiful.’

Knowledge Point: Like nō, rō is the result of vowel assimilation: it is derived from PNP *loa. Unlike nō, rō is not used in the noun phrase, but it does occur occasionally in numeral phrases (see \REF{ex:4.28} on p.~\pageref{ex:4.28}).
Content 1: \gll Mo ai rō kona hore iho hai \ꞌārote e pu\ꞌa era e ono \ꞌo \textbf{ka} \textbf{va}\ꞌ\textbf{u} \textbf{rō} \textbf{atu} \ꞌuei. | \gls if exist EMPH place cut just_then INS plough IPFV cover DIST NUM six or CNTG eight EMPH away ox | \glt ‘When a field was ploughed for the first time, it was ploughed with six or even eight oxen.’

Knowledge Point: Rō may emphasise the reality of a situation: ‘really’.\footnote{\label{fn:349}Examples such as \REF{ex:7.116} might suggest that rō means ‘very’. However, rō (unlike \ili{Tahitian} roa) is not a common way to express a high degree; rather, this is expressed using \textit{hope{\ꞌ}a} ‘last’ or \textit{ri{\ꞌ}ari{\ꞌ}a} ‘terribly’.}
Content 1: \gll Te parauti\ꞌa, \textbf{e} \textbf{haŋa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā} a au ki a kōrua ko koro. | \gls ART truth IPFV love EMPH CONT PROP 1SG to PROP 2PL PROM Dad | \glt ‘The truth is, I do love you and Dad.’

Knowledge Point: When rō emphasises the reality of the clause, there may be a connotation of counterexpectation\is{Counterexpectation}. In \REF{ex:7.118} this happens in a question, in \REF{ex:7.119} as reply to a question.
Content 1: \gll ¿\textbf{E} \textbf{haŋa} \textbf{rō} koe mo oho ki hiva mo hāpī? | \gls ~IPFV want EMPH 2SG for go to continent for learn | \glt ‘Do you (really) want to go to the continent to study?’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌIna \ꞌō pēaha kai ŋaro\ꞌa e te nu\ꞌu hūrio i te roŋo rivariva o te \ꞌAtua? \textbf{I} \textbf{ŋaro\ꞌa} \textbf{rō}. | \gls ~~NEG really perhaps NEG.PFV perceive AG ART people Jew ACC ART message good:RED of ART God PFV perceive EMPH | \glt ‘Have the Jews perhaps not heard the good news about God? They have heard it.’

Knowledge Point: As indicated in the previous section, directionals\is{Directional} signal movement with respect to a deictic centre. In direct speech, the deictic centre is usually the speaker. This means that in a conversation, mai usually indicates a movement towards the speaker as in \REF{ex:7.122} below, while atu indicates a movement away from the speaker. The latter movement may be towards the addressee as in \REF{ex:7.123}, or away from the speaker in another direction as in \REF{ex:7.124}.
Content 1: \gll ¿Ko ai koe e eke \textbf{mai} ena? | \gls ~PROM who 2SG IPFV go_up hither MED | \glt ‘Who are you (who are) coming up?’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌĪ au he oho \textbf{atu}. | \gls IMM 1SG NTR go away | \glt ‘I am coming (towards you) right now.’
Content 3: \gll He e\ꞌa \textbf{atu} a au \ꞌi te hora nei. | \gls NTR go_out away PROP 1SG at ART time now | \glt ‘I am going away now.’

Knowledge Point: In the next examples, it is the direct object which moves: towards the speaker in \REF{ex:7.125}, away from the speaker towards the addressee in \REF{ex:7.126}.
Content 1: \gll ¡Ka hoa \textbf{mai} a nei! | \gls ~IMP throw hither by PROX | \glt ‘Throw (the body) here!’
Content 2: \gll ¡Ka haro \textbf{atu}! | \gls ~IMP pull away | \glt ‘Pull (the net, from here) towards you!’

Knowledge Point: In the following examples, there is no physical movement of a participant or object, but a flow of information from the speaker to the addressee. In \REF{ex:7.127} the speaker is the subject, so the information moves away from the speaker; hence the use of atu. In \REF{ex:7.128} the speaker is addressed by the subject of the clause, so the flow of information is directed towards the speaker; hence the use of mai.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira e haka \ꞌite \textbf{atu} ena i te roŋo rivariva nei. | \gls because_of ANA IPFV CAUS know away MED ACC ART message good:RED PROX | \glt ‘Therefore (I) make this good news known (to you).’
Content 2: \gll ¿He aha rā nei o te me\ꞌe nei a koro ka kī \textbf{mai} nei? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS PROX of ART thing PROX PROP Dad CNTG say hither PROX | \glt ‘What is this thing that Dad is saying (to us)?’

Knowledge Point: As directionals\is{Directional} indicate the direction of movement of a participant, object, or information, a directional\is{Directional} may be sufficient to indicate the recipient, addressee or goal of an event: kī mai ‘say toward’ indicates that something was said to me (or us). Therefore, the recipient, addressee or goal does not need to be stated separately.\footnote{\label{fn:351}For this reason, \citet[4]{Wittenstein1978} calls mai and atu in Rapa Nui “directional\is{Directional} pronouns”.} This is the case in \REF{ex:7.128} above and in \REF{ex:7.130} below:
Content 1: \gll ¿He aha rā nei o te me\ꞌe nei a koro ka kī \textbf{mai} nei? | \gls ~PRED what INTENS PROX of ART thing PROX PROP Dad CNTG say hither PROX | \glt ‘What is this thing that Dad is saying (to us)?’
Content 2: \gll —¡A Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{mai} mo turu o māua! —¡\ꞌĒē, a Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{atu}! | \gls ~~~~PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say hither for go_down of 1DU.EXCL ~~~~yes~~ PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say away | \glt ‘—Te Manu said (to me) that we (=he and I) should go down! —OK, so Te Manu told (you)!’

Knowledge Point: When the subject is also left implicit, the directional\is{Directional} mai or atu may be the only clue for participant reference. In \REF{ex:7.131}, the subject is not expressed. Atu indicates that the request was directed from the speaker (‘we’) to Meherio, while the help requested went from Meherio to the speaker.\footnote{\label{fn:352}The start of the sentence is syntactically unusual. The syntax of \textit{{\ꞌ}āmui} (a borrowing from \ili{Tahitian}, where it is a verb ‘to get together, be united’) is very flexible in Rapa Nui. In this case, a \ili{Tahitian} construction seems to be used, in which i N VP (‘to/at me said’) may function as a temporal clause (‘when I said’); this construction is not attested otherwise in Rapa Nui.}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĀmui i a Meherio e kī \textbf{atu} era... mo hā\ꞌū\ꞌū \textbf{mai}, \ꞌina he hā\ꞌū\ꞌū rō \textbf{mai}. | \gls moreover at PROP Meherio IPFV say away DIST for help hither NEG NTR help EMPH hither | \glt ‘Moreover, when (we) told Meherio to help (us), (she) didn’t help (us).’

Knowledge Point: In the examples so far, atu indicates either a movement from speaker to addressee, or a movement away from speaker and hearer in an unspecified direction as in \REF{ex:7.124}.\footnote{\label{fn:353}As mentioned above, according to \citet[34]{Clark1976}, *atu in \is{Proto-Polynesian}PPN means ‘away from the speaker’.} However, atu does not always imply a movement away from the speaker: it may indicate a movement from another place or participant towards the addressee. The following examples illustrate this.
Content 1: \gll He e\ꞌa \textbf{atu} a au \ꞌi te hora nei. | \gls NTR go_out away PROP 1SG at ART time now | \glt ‘I am going away now.’

Knowledge Point: An example like \REF{ex:7.133} is striking, because it is not at all clear how the location of origin can be considered the deictic centre: the place where Hoto Vari comes from, is not relevant at all in the story; it is not even mentioned. In other words, the use of atu seems to be motivated entirely by its destination (the second person), not by a deictic centre. This may thus be an exception to the rule (formulated e.g. by \citealt[285]{Hooper2002} for \ili{Tokelauan}) that the use of directionals\is{Directional} always implies the existence of a deictic centre.
Content 1: \gll E tu\ꞌu haka\ꞌou \textbf{atu} \ꞌā a Hoto Vari, e haka~poreko haka\ꞌou \textbf{atu} \ꞌā hai \ꞌarero... | \gls IPFV arrive again away CONT PROP Hoto Vari IPFV stick_out again away CONT INS tongue | \glt ‘When Hoto Vari comes again (to you), and sticks out his tongue (to you)...’

Knowledge Point: These example also show that the sense of atu cannot be captured in a single definition: atu does not always express movement away from the speaker (see (\ref{ex:7.132}–\ref{ex:7.133})), but neither does it always express movement towards the addressee (see \REF{ex:7.124}). Either one is a sufficient criterion for using atu; neither is a necessary criterion.
Content 1: \gll Mo haŋa ō\ꞌou mo haŋa \textbf{atu} o tētahi manu era, e haŋa ra\ꞌe e koe. | \gls if want POSS.2SG.O for love away of other bird DIST EXH love first AG 2SG | \glt ‘If you want other birds to love (you), you should love (them) first.’
Content 2: \gll E tu\ꞌu haka\ꞌou \textbf{atu} \ꞌā a Hoto Vari, e haka~poreko haka\ꞌou \textbf{atu} \ꞌā hai \ꞌarero... | \gls IPFV arrive again away CONT PROP Hoto Vari IPFV stick_out again away CONT INS tongue | \glt ‘When Hoto Vari comes again (to you), and sticks out his tongue (to you)...’
Content 3: \gll He e\ꞌa \textbf{atu} a au \ꞌi te hora nei. | \gls NTR go_out away PROP 1SG at ART time now | \glt ‘I am going away now.’

Knowledge Point: This apparent exception to the rule may have to do with a general tendency of the verb \textit{e{\ꞌ}a} ‘go out’ to be followed by mai rather than atu. As discussed in \sectref{sec:7.5.2} below, \textit{e{\ꞌ}a} commonly takes mai while it rarely takes atu; a similar tendency is discernible for other motion verbs\is{Verb!motion}. This means that the directional\is{Directional} after \textit{e{\ꞌ}a} tends to point to the destination, the place where the subject is going to, as the centre of attention. In this way it provides the reader/hearer with a subtle signal that this location is significant as the location where the next events are going to happen. Notice that in \REF{ex:7.136} above, \textit{e{\ꞌ}a mai} occurs in a cohesive clause, which provides a bridge between the previous scene (in the house) and the next one (in the village). Mai contributes to paving the way for the change of location and the next scene.
Content 1: \gll I e\ꞌa haka\ꞌou \textbf{mai} era tū ŋāŋata era mai te hare era o tū rū\ꞌau era... | \gls PFV go_out again hither DIST DEM men DIST from ART house DIST of DEM old_woman DIST | \glt ‘When those men came out again of the house of that old woman...’

Knowledge Point: Now what if the movement concerns the protagonist himself, i.e. when Huri a Vai himself moves to a different location? \citet[142–143]{Levinsohn2007} points out that in such cases, languages tend to use one of two strategies: the deictic centre is either a fixed geographical location or it is the next location, i.e. the destination of the movement. As it turns out, in Rapa Nui narrative the second strategy is predominant: when the protagonist moves, mai is used to point to the location where the next events are going to happen.\footnote{\label{fn:355}In the preceding section, the same tendency was observed in the story Nuahine Rima Roa; see example \REF{ex:7.136} and discussion.} The following example illustrates this:
Content 1: \gll I e\ꞌa haka\ꞌou \textbf{mai} era tū ŋāŋata era mai te hare era o tū rū\ꞌau era... | \gls PFV go_out again hither DIST DEM men DIST from ART house DIST of DEM old_woman DIST | \glt ‘When those men came out again of the house of that old woman...’

Knowledge Point: The deictic centre may also be a minor participant, provided this participant is significant in the scene in question. See \REF{ex:7.140} in the next section for an example.
Content 1: \gll He raŋi \textbf{atu} ia e \ꞌOho Takatore... Terā ia ka pāhono \textbf{mai} e Poio... I raŋi \textbf{mai} era e Poio pē ira... | \gls NTR call away then AG Oho Takatore then then CNTG answer hither AG Poio PFV call hither DIST AG Poio like ANA | \glt ‘Oho Takatore shouted... Then Poio answered... When Poio had called out like that...’

Knowledge Point: There is a clear difference between these two examples: in \REF{ex:7.143}, Huri a Vai is hiding from his enemies, he is lying low to avoid being detected. In \REF{ex:7.144}, Kainga is not just hiding away; he is lying in ambush, waiting for Vaha to come by. In other words, the hiding in \REF{ex:7.143} is self-directed, oriented inwards, while the hiding in \REF{ex:7.144} is outward-looking, with the attention away from the person hiding. It is no coincidence that in the first case mai is used, indicating orientation towards the subject as deictic centre, while in the second case atu is used, pointing away from the subject. In other texts as well, piko mai is commonly used when people hide from others, while piko atu is used of people lying in ambush, spying on someone else (cf. \citealt[12]{Fuller1980}). While there is no movement involved, the directionals\is{Directional} indicate \textsc{orientation} with respect to the deictic centre.\footnote{\label{fn:357}\citet[1751]{Hooper2004} discusses a similar function of directionals\is{Directional} in \ili{Tokelauan}. She points out (with reference to \citealt{Jackendoff1983}) that a path (i.e. a directional\is{Directional} movement) may play various roles: an object may traverse a path, but it may also be oriented along a path, facing an entity (in this case, the deictic centre).}
Content 1: \gll ...tū pū era o Huri \ꞌa Vai e \textbf{piko} \textbf{mai} era \ꞌi roto. | \gls ~~~DEM hole DIST of Huri a Vai IPFV hide hither DIST at inside | \glt ‘...the hole where Huri a Vai was hiding.’
Content 2: \gll He e\ꞌa he oho mai a tū ara era \ꞌi ira a Kāiŋa e \textbf{piko} \textbf{atu} era. | \gls NTR go_out NTR go hither by DEM way DIST at ANA PROP Kainga IPFV hide away DIST | \glt ‘(Vaha) came out by that road where Kainga was hiding.’
Content 3: \gll ...tū pū era o Huri \ꞌa Vai e \textbf{piko} \textbf{mai} era \ꞌi roto. | \gls ~~~DEM hole DIST of Huri a Vai IPFV hide hither DIST at inside | \glt ‘...the hole where Huri a Vai was hiding.’
Content 4: \gll He e\ꞌa he oho mai a tū ara era \ꞌi ira a Kāiŋa e \textbf{piko} \textbf{atu} era. | \gls NTR go_out NTR go hither by DEM way DIST at ANA PROP Kainga IPFV hide away DIST | \glt ‘(Vaha) came out by that road where Kainga was hiding.’

Subsection: To use or not to use a directional\label{sec:7.5.3
Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Participant reference} As discussed in \sectref{sec:7.5.1.1}, ex. (\ref{ex:7.130}–\ref{ex:7.131}), directionals\is{Directional} may play a role in participant reference: directionals\is{Directional} indicate whether a participant is at the origin or the goal of the movement, so they may be used instead of an overt subject or object. This accounts for many occurrences of directionals\is{Directional}, for example with speech verbs\is{Verb!speech} in direct discourse, as in \REF{ex:7.130}.
Content 1: \gll —¡A Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{mai} mo turu o māua! —¡\ꞌĒē, a Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{atu}! | \gls ~~~~PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say hither for go_down of 1DU.EXCL ~~~~yes~~ PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say away | \glt ‘—Te Manu said (to me) that we (=he and I) should go down! —OK, so Te Manu told (you)!’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌĀmui i a Meherio e kī \textbf{atu} era... mo hā\ꞌū\ꞌū \textbf{mai}, \ꞌina he hā\ꞌū\ꞌū rō \textbf{mai}. | \gls moreover at PROP Meherio IPFV say away DIST for help hither NEG NTR help EMPH hither | \glt ‘Moreover, when (we) told Meherio to help (us), (she) didn’t help (us).’
Content 3: \gll —¡A Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{mai} mo turu o māua! —¡\ꞌĒē, a Te Manu ho\ꞌi i kī \textbf{atu}! | \gls ~~~~PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say hither for go_down of 1DU.EXCL ~~~~yes~~ PROP Te Manu indeed PFV say away | \glt ‘—Te Manu said (to me) that we (=he and I) should go down! —OK, so Te Manu told (you)!’

Subsection: To use or not to use a directional\label{sec:7.5.3
Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Distance} Possibly, directionals\is{Directional} tend to be used when there is a significant distance between the origin and the goal of movement, e.g. between the speaker and the addressee. I have not found many instances where this is is the only factor involved, but there are examples which can plausibly be explained this way. In \REF{ex:7.153}, \textit{e{\ꞌ}a} ‘go out (of the house)’ is not marked by a directional\is{Directional}, while oho ‘go’ is; the latter involves movement over a considerable distance, while the former does not.
Content 1: \gll Ka e\ꞌa koe ka haka rivariva i te poki, ka oho \textbf{atu} kōrua ki Haŋa Piko. | \gls IMP go_out 2SG IMP CAUS good:RED ACC ART child IMP go away 2PL to Hanga Piko | \glt ‘Go outside and prepare the child, and go to Hanga Piko.’

Knowledge Point: In addition, PVD\is{Demonstrative!postverbal}’s\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} are used in relative clauses\is{Clause!relative!bare} (\sectref{sec:11.4.5}; see also \REF{ex:7.161} below).
Content 1: \gll tā\ꞌana vānaŋa \textbf{kī} \textbf{atu} \textbf{ena} ki a koe | \gls POSS.3SG.A word say away MED to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘the words he spoke to you’

Knowledge Point: Nei often marks an action performed by the speaker, i.e. in the first person, as in \REF{ex:7.154}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira a au \textbf{i} \textbf{iri} \textbf{mai} \textbf{nei} ki a koe. | \gls because_of ANA PROP 1SG PFV ascend hither PROX to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘Therefore I have come up to you.’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, the event may take place near the speaker as in \REF{ex:7.155}, or is directed towards the location of the speaker as in \REF{ex:7.156}:
Content 1: \gll Pē nei \textbf{e} \textbf{kī} \textbf{nei} e te nu\ꞌu nei: ko mate \ꞌana koe. | \gls like PROX IPFV say PROX AG ART people PROX PRF die CONT 2SG | \glt ‘This is what these people say: you have died.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\ꞌI hē rā a Vaha \textbf{e} ta\ꞌe \textbf{tu\ꞌu} \textbf{mai} \textbf{nei}? | \gls ~at CQ INTENS PROP Vaha IPFV CONNEG arrive hither PROX | \glt ‘Where is Vaha, that he doesn’t arrive?’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally nei has a temporal rather than a spatial function. In \REF{ex:7.157}, the speaker talks about something habitually taking place in the present.
Content 1: \gll Te vaka o te hora nei, \textbf{e} \textbf{haha\ꞌo} \textbf{nei} te aroaro \ꞌi ruŋa o te kavakava mau \ꞌana. | \gls ART boat of ART time PROX IPFV insert PROX ART lining at above of ART rib really IDENT | \glt ‘The boats of nowadays, they put the lining on top of the ribs.’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, nei in the verb phrase may co-occur with nei in the subject or another noun phrase in the clause (cf. also \REF{ex:7.155} above).
Content 1: \gll Pē nei \textbf{e} \textbf{kī} \textbf{nei} e te nu\ꞌu nei: ko mate \ꞌana koe. | \gls like PROX IPFV say PROX AG ART people PROX PRF die CONT 2SG | \glt ‘This is what these people say: you have died.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes the action takes place near the addressee, as in \REF{ex:7.161}, or at a little distance from both speaker and addressee, as in \REF{ex:7.162}.
Content 1: \gll tā\ꞌana vānaŋa \textbf{kī} \textbf{atu} \textbf{ena} ki a koe | \gls POSS.3SG.A word say away MED to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘the words he spoke to you’
Content 2: \gll Mo kōrua ho\ꞌi e u\ꞌi, ana tu\ꞌu mai a Hare mai tō\ꞌona kona ena \textbf{e} \textbf{ŋaro} \textbf{mai} \textbf{ena}. | \gls for 2PL indeed IPFV look IRR arrive hither PROP Hare from POSS.3SG.O place MED IPFV disappear hither MED | \glt ‘You will see whether Hare comes from the place where he has disappeared.’

Knowledge Point: Notice that in \REF{ex:7.162}, postverbal ena is paralleled by ena in the preceding noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll Mo kōrua ho\ꞌi e u\ꞌi, ana tu\ꞌu mai a Hare mai tō\ꞌona kona ena \textbf{e} \textbf{ŋaro} \textbf{mai} \textbf{ena}. | \gls for 2PL indeed IPFV look IRR arrive hither PROP Hare from POSS.3SG.O place MED IPFV disappear hither MED | \glt ‘You will see whether Hare comes from the place where he has disappeared.’

Knowledge Point: Ena may also have a temporal function: it refers to a moment somewhat removed from the present. This may be the near past as in \REF{ex:7.163}, or the near future as in \REF{ex:7.164}:
Content 1: \gll te ŋā me\ꞌe nei au i tataku \textbf{i} \textbf{oho} \textbf{atu} \textbf{ena} | \gls ART PL thing PROX 1SG PFV tell PFV go away MED | \glt ‘the things I have (just) been telling about’
Content 2: \gll He mana\ꞌu nō te me\ꞌe nei ō\ꞌoku \textbf{ka} \textbf{kī} \textbf{atu} \textbf{ena}. | \gls PRED thought just ART thing PROX POSS.1SG.O CNTG say away MED | \glt ‘What I am about to say, is just a thought.’

Knowledge Point: Other PVDs\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} are only used when there is a specific reason to do so. As discussed above, nei is used when the action is performed by the speaker, takes place close to the speaker, takes place in the present, or is metaphorically proximate in discourse. Likewise, ena can be used when the action is performed by or near to the hearer, takes place at a moderate distance, or at a time somewhat close to the present. This does not mean that nei or ena is always used whenever one of these conditions is fulfilled. Era, being the default PVD\is{Demonstrative!postverbal}, can be used for an action performed by the speaker as in (\ref{ex:7.166}–\ref{ex:7.167}), or an action performed by the hearer as in (\ref{ex:7.168}–\ref{ex:7.169}). In all these cases, however, distance is involved: in (\ref{ex:7.167}–\ref{ex:7.169}) the event takes place in the past; in \REF{ex:7.166} the event is hypothetical, and therefore also removed from the here and now.
Content 1: \gll ...\ꞌai au \textbf{e} \textbf{u\ꞌi} \textbf{mai} \textbf{era} mai ruŋa ki a koe. | \gls ~~~there 1SG IPFV look hither DIST from above to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘(If I were that bird,) I would look at you from above.’
Content 2: \gll A au ho\ꞌi \textbf{i} \textbf{raŋi} \textbf{atu} \textbf{era} ki a koe... | \gls PROP 1SG indeed PFV call away DIST to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘Indeed, I called out to you...’
Content 3: \gll Pē nei koe \textbf{i} \textbf{kī} \textbf{mai} \textbf{era} ki a au: he tu\ꞌu mai a Vaha \ꞌarīnā. | \gls like PROX 2SG PFV say hither DIST to PROP 1SG NTR arrive hither PROP Vaha later_today | \glt ‘You said to me that Vaha would arrive today.’
Content 4: \gll ¿Pē hē kōrua \textbf{e} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{era}? | \gls ~like CQ 2PL IPFV talk DIST | \glt ‘What were you(pl) talking about?’
Content 5: \gll A au ho\ꞌi \textbf{i} \textbf{raŋi} \textbf{atu} \textbf{era} ki a koe... | \gls PROP 1SG indeed PFV call away DIST to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘Indeed, I called out to you...’
Content 6: \gll ¿Pē hē kōrua \textbf{e} \textbf{vānaŋa} \textbf{era}? | \gls ~like CQ 2PL IPFV talk DIST | \glt ‘What were you(pl) talking about?’
Content 7: \gll ...\ꞌai au \textbf{e} \textbf{u\ꞌi} \textbf{mai} \textbf{era} mai ruŋa ki a koe. | \gls ~~~there 1SG IPFV look hither DIST from above to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘(If I were that bird,) I would look at you from above.’

Knowledge Point: In verb-initial clauses, ai is almost as common as with oblique preverbal constituents (72%), a situation not found in other languages. Possibly the use of ai in these clauses can be explained to some extent in terms of inter-clausal (rather than intra-clausal) anaphora\is{Anaphora}. For example, in \REF{ex:7.170} ai could be explained as providing an anaphoric\is{Anaphora} link with the preceding clause.
Content 1: \gll ¿I mamae rō koe \textbf{i} \textbf{hiŋa} \textbf{ai}? | \gls ~PFV pain EMPH 2SG PFV fall PVP | \glt ‘Did you get hurt when you fell down?’

Subsection: The syntax of SVCs in Rapa Nui\label{sec:7.7.2
Knowledge Point: Aspectuals – ko in \REF{ex:7.171}, i in \REF{ex:7.172}, he in \REF{ex:7.173} – are repeated before each verb. Postverbal \textit{{\ꞌ}ā} \REF{ex:7.171} and era \REF{ex:7.172} occur only after the second verb.\footnote{\label{fn:375}Both are obligatory, given the construction: perfect ko is always accompanied by \textit{{\ꞌ}ā} (\sectref{sec:7.2.7}), while i V era in \REF{ex:7.172} marks a cohesive clause (\sectref{sec:11.6.2.1}).} In \REF{ex:7.173} – a tripartite SVC – i tū manu era is the direct object of the first verb \textit{ma{\ꞌ}u}, yet it occurs after the SVC construction as a whole. \REF{ex:7.174} shows that subordinators like \textit{{\ꞌ}o} are repeated in the same way as aspectuals.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĒē, \textbf{ko} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} \textbf{ko} \textbf{hoki} \ꞌā ki tō\ꞌona kona. | \gls yes PRF carry PRF return CONT to POSS.3SG.O place | \glt ‘Yes, they carried it back to its place.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{hoki} \textbf{i} \textbf{turu} mai era ararua a rā \ꞌā... | \gls PFV return PFV go_down hither DIST the_two by DIST IDENT | \glt ‘When they returned together (with downwards movement) by that place...’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} \textbf{he} \textbf{iri} \textbf{he} \textbf{oho} i tū manu era ki te hare pure. | \gls NTR carry NTR ascend NTR go ACC DEM animal DIST to ART house pray | \glt ‘They carried the animal up to the church.’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌĒē, \textbf{ko} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} \textbf{ko} \textbf{hoki} \ꞌā ki tō\ꞌona kona. | \gls yes PRF carry PRF return CONT to POSS.3SG.O place | \glt ‘Yes, they carried it back to its place.’
Content 5: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{hoki} \textbf{i} \textbf{turu} mai era ararua a rā \ꞌā... | \gls PFV return PFV go_down hither DIST the_two by DIST IDENT | \glt ‘When they returned together (with downwards movement) by that place...’
Content 6: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{hoki} \textbf{i} \textbf{turu} mai era ararua a rā \ꞌā... | \gls PFV return PFV go_down hither DIST the_two by DIST IDENT | \glt ‘When they returned together (with downwards movement) by that place...’
Content 7: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} \textbf{he} \textbf{iri} \textbf{he} \textbf{oho} i tū manu era ki te hare pure. | \gls NTR carry NTR ascend NTR go ACC DEM animal DIST to ART house pray | \glt ‘They carried the animal up to the church.’
Content 8: \gll ...\textbf{\ꞌo} \textbf{pe\ꞌe} \textbf{\ꞌo} \textbf{oho} te māuiui ki tētahi nu\ꞌu sano ena e noho mai ena. | \gls ~~~lest infect lest go ART sick to other people healthy MED IPFV stay hither MED | \glt ‘...lest the disease keeps infecting other people who are still healthy.’

Subsection: The syntax of SVCs in Rapa Nui\label{sec:7.7.2
Knowledge Point: These examples also show how SVCs can be distinguished from coordinated clauses\is{Coordination}. As verb arguments are often omitted in discourse, a string of verbal clauses may consist of just A/M V A/M V... (see e.g. \REF{ex:7.3} on p.~\pageref{ex:7.3}); such a string may at first sight be indistinguishable from an SVC. Diagnostics for SVCs are: the omission of postverbal particles after the first verb, and the placement of the direct object of a verb after the next verb (even when the latter is intransitive\is{Verb!intransitive}). SVCs can also be recognised by semantic criteria, as they often express a single event; this will be discussed in the next section.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} e\ꞌa mai a nua \textbf{he} haka rivariva \textbf{he} oti \textbf{he} e\ꞌa \textbf{he} turu ararua ko Eva \textbf{he} tu\ꞌu ki Haŋa Piko. | \gls NTR go_out hither PROP Mum NTR CAUS good:RED NTR finish NTR go_out NTR go_down the_two PROM Eva NTR arrive to Hanga Piko | \glt ‘Mum went out, she made preparations, she finished, she went out, she went down with Eva, they arrived in Hanga Piko.’

Subsection: The syntax of SVCs in Rapa Nui\label{sec:7.7.2
Knowledge Point: In nominalised\is{Verb!nominalised} SVCs, the determiner is repeated. Any preposition preceding the nominalised verb\is{Verb!nominalised} is repeated as well, e.g. pe in \REF{ex:7.176}:\footnote{\label{fn:376}\REF{ex:7.175} is an habitual\is{Aspect!habitual} actor-emphatic\is{Actor-emphatic construction} construction (\sectref{sec:8.6.3}).}
Content 1: \gll Te pūai, pa\ꞌi, o rāua \textbf{pe} \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋaro} \textbf{pe} \textbf{te} \textbf{oho} nō. | \gls ART strong in_fact of 3PL toward ART disappear toward ART go just | \glt ‘Their power will gradually disappear.’
Content 2: \gll O te naonao toretore \textbf{te} \textbf{haka} \textbf{pe\ꞌe} \textbf{te} \textbf{oho} te māuiui he renke. | \gls of ART mosquito stripe ART CAUS infect CAUS go ART sick PRED dengue | \glt ‘It is the striped mosquito which keeps spreading dengue disease.’

Knowledge Point: Oho\is{oho ‘to go’} ‘go’ is by far the most common V2 in SVCs. It often expresses extended duration\is{Aspect!continuous}, indicating that the action expressed by V1 goes on for a while. As \REF{ex:7.180} shows, when V1 is an adjective, the SVC expresses an ongoing process.
Content 1: \gll He rahi te ta\ꞌu \ꞌe \textbf{he} \textbf{nuinui} \textbf{he} \textbf{oho} tū manu era. | \gls NTR many ART year and NTR big:RED NTR go DEM bird DIST | \glt ‘Many years passed and the bird grew up (got bigger and bigger).’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:7.7.3}.2~ Direction} V2 may be a motion verb\is{Verb!motion} specifying the direction in which the action expressed by V1 takes place. The motion verb\is{Verb!motion} may be iri ‘go up’, turu ‘go down’ or hoki ‘go back, return’. The idea of movement itself may be expressed by V1 (e.g. haro in \REF{ex:7.183}), but in other cases such as \REF{ex:7.184}, V1 by itself does not express movement.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{haro} \textbf{i} \textbf{iri} era he tu\ꞌu ki ruŋa. | \gls PFV pull PFV ascend DIST NTR arrive to above | \glt ‘When they had pulled (the net) up, it arrived on top.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{kai} \textbf{he} \textbf{turu} i tā\ꞌana tūava. | \gls NTR eat NTR go_down ACC POSS.3SG.A goyava | \glt ‘He went down, eating his goyavas.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:7.7.3}.4~ Other} In other cases, both verbs describe an event. The verbs may be closely related or near-synonyms as in \REF{ex:7.190}, both expressing the same event under different angles; they may also describe different aspects of the same event as in \REF{ex:7.191} (‘ask in writing’ or ‘write to ask’). Alternatively, they express sequential events considered to be part of the same macro-event, as in \REF{ex:7.192}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{veveri} \textbf{ko} \textbf{\ꞌara} \ꞌana a au \ꞌi te kona nei \ꞌana. | \gls PRF startled PRF wake_up CONT PROP 1SG at ART place PROX IDENT | \glt ‘I woke up with a start in this same place.’
Content 2: \gll Hora nei he pāhono atu au i te me\ꞌe \textbf{pāpa\ꞌi} \textbf{\ꞌui} mai era e kōrua. | \gls time PROX NTR answer away 1SG ACC ART thing write ask hither DIST AG 2PL | \glt ‘Now I will answer the things you wrote (and) asked me.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{kimi} \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ohu} a nua. | \gls PROM ART search PROM ART shout PROP Mum | \glt ‘Mum searched (the child), shouting.’
